@criticalneuro @kaixhin I'd be interested to read a longer treatment of your thoughts on the paper Ida, if you ever find yourself with the extra time to write some of them down. As valuable as opinion papers are, critiques of opinion papers are even better.

@criticalneuro While I agree, I still think that it is a well written paper that can serve as a useful introduction to this set of ideas for those unfamiliar with them. And many on the ML side of things are. 🤷

@criticalneuro I agree that what is proposed in the paper isn't so novel, especially from the neuro-side. I think the significant contribution is to provide a formalism against which to compare ML models. And by the proposed criteria, most ML models are indeed retrospective.

@criticalneuro It also provides a nice constraint on the typically vague notion of "OOD" generalization in the ML literature. In natural intelligence we see generalization is "towards the future," and it makes sense to try to see that kind of generalization in AI as well.

@criticalneuro I think the distinction between "prospective" vs "retrospective" learning is a useful one. The majority of so-called predictive models in AI are actually retrospective according to their definition.

This is a great paper, and aligns with a lot of the thinking I've recently been doing about the relationship between natural and artificial intelligence. Excited to see how this kind of perspective will inspire new approaches to agent development in the coming years. https://t.co/QaO2wXdu5A

Sampling time though is another matter. The model produces great samples, but that quality comes at the cost of increased computation time. For many, it may not be worth it to spend minutes generating your images when a VAE/GAN could do it in seconds. 4/5

I open-sourced my code which you can check out here: https://t.co/qygbbxnaJe. It is written in PyTorch/Lightning and works with MNIST and CIFAR datasets. As long as you have a GPU, you can train the generative model for these datasets in a matter of minutes. 3/5

The idea behind these models is very clever, and they can be implemented straightforwardly as well. Put simply, you just train a model to predict the noise added to an image. Once trained, you iteratively use that model to go from random noise a generated sample. 2/5

@bonzajplc TF1.0 will be deprecated at some point, so we needed to either switch to PyTorch or TF2.0. Both have similar benefits, but we felt that writing PyTorch code was a little bit more intuitive and performant compared to TF2.0. Of course there is subjectivity in that decision.

@khaled_Jabr @marksaroufim From idea to implementation, PyTorch is easily twice as fast. It is also much simpler to debug and reason about. As I mentioned above though, the final "optimization" step before the code is production ready does take a little more effort than in TF.

@marksaroufim Most of what we've had to deal with have actually been relative slow downs. PyTorch is more flexible and user-friendly, but that comes with less optimization out of the box compared with TF1.0. We evaluated TF2.0 as well, and it came with more or less the same set of trade-offs.

Rewriting our TF1.0 codebase in PyTorch has been a months-long effort by many on our team, myself included. Long-term, it is going to help us accelerate development of future DeepRL algorithms in ML-Agents. We'd appreciate folks trying it out and letting us know their experience. https://t.co/AT5l98rw9I

@sdizme @togelius Theoretically there isn't a difference, but I'd say that humans are more likely to mis-specify negative rewards. One example is giving a negative time-penalty reward for goal-directed nav. It can result in agent learning to "kill" itself before it learns to reach the goal.

@sampattij Yep. In fact, I think imitation can aid in leading to more general-purpose AI. But imitation in this case simplifies the problem, rather than acting as a stepping stone to learning more complex behaviors.

@NandoDF Completely agree! Learning from demonstrations is a very important research topic. My article is about how using a fixed deterministic environment with a single "optimal" path makes for less compelling results when doing so.

@jseakle @AwokeKnowing @hardmaru Exactly. Demonstrations can be a great way to learn, and indeed is how we learn as humans. The difference is that we get demonstrations and are able to transfer them to new situations. That isn't what is being studied meaningfully in the Montezuma's results though...

@hardmaru @andrey_kurenkov @gradientpub As @andrey_kurenkov says below, I actually don't have a problem with demonstrations in general. The issue is that since Montezuma's is a fixed deterministic environment, having demonstrations of the optimal path through it make the problem much less interesting.

@erwincoumans @hardmaru @shimon8282 There is always just to try learning end-to-end using the reward signal. In that case you get a representation that is specific to the task. The problem is that the reward signal is very poor. The trick is to come up with some richer signal that is still task relevant.

@erwincoumans @hardmaru @shimon8282 I guess the fundamental issue is that if you have a finite representation, there has to be some way of deciding what should and shouldn't go in it. If you are using that representation to solve a task, it should probably include task-relevant things, and not task-irrelevant ones.
